column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=Electronic power converters as drivers for DC motors have been recently studied .
#Text=According to the literature on power converters , the Buck , the Boost , and the Buck-Boost topologies are the most used .
#Text=The Buck topology received the most attention .

#Text=This is , in part , due to the fact that the mathematical model of the Buck topology is linear and , compared with the Boost and the Buck-Boost topologies , the Buck topology does not have a nonminimum phase output variable .
#Text=As the present paper focuses on the Buck power converter as a driver for a DC motor , a review of state-of-the-art of this topic is presented below .
#Text=1.1 .
#Text=Related Work
#Text=The literature reviewed has been divided into two approaches : ( 1 ) DC/DC Buck converter – DC motor systems and ( 2 ) DC/DC Buck converter – inverter – DC motor systems .

#Text=Regarding a DC motor when it is fed by a DC/DC Buck converter , the most relevant literature is the following ; Lyshevski , in , designed a nonlinear PI control that regulates the velocity of the motor shaft . Ahmad et al. , in , presented a performance assessment of the PI , fuzzy PI , and LQR controls for the tracking problem .
#Text=Bingöl and Paçaci reported , in , a virtual laboratory based on neural networks to control the angular velocity .

#Text=Sira-Ramírez and Oliver-Salazar used the concepts of active disturbance rejection and differential flatness to design a tracking control for two configurations of a DC/DC Buck converter connected to a DC motor .
#Text=In , Silva-Ortigoza et al. introduced a two-stage sensorless tracking control based on flatness , whose implementation was executed via a – -modulator .

#Text=In , Hoyos et al. designed a robust adaptive quasi-sliding mode regulation control , which is generated through the zero average dynamics ( ZAD ) technique and a fixed point inducting control ( FPIC ) .

#Text=Later , Silva-Ortigoza et al. proposed a robust hierarchical control approach based on differential flatness in . Wei et al. in reported a robust adaptive controller based on dynamic surface and sliding mode .

#Text=A two-stage controller based on sliding mode plus PI control and flatness was reported by Silva-Ortigoza et al. in . Hernández-Guzmán et al. , in , proposed a simple control scheme by using sliding mode , to regulate the converter current , and three PI controls .
#Text=These latter to regulate the converter voltage , the motor current , and the angular velocity .

#Text=Moreover , via sensorless load torque estimation schemes , a passive tracking control based on the exact tracking error dynamics was proposed by Kumar and Thilagar in . Khubalkar et al. , in , presented the design and realization of standalone digital fractional order PID control for the Buck converter – DC motor system , where the dynamic particle swarm optimization ( dPSO ) technique is used to tune the gains and the order of the control .
#Text=By using the concept of differential flatness and a derivative-free nonlinear Kalman filter , Rigatos et al. , in , designed a control to solve the trajectory tracking problem .
#Text=Another solution was proposed by Nizami et al. in , where a neuroadaptive backstepping tracking control was developed for the system .

#Text=The dynamic analysis of the Buck converter that uses the combined ZAD-FPIC technique to control the speed of the DC motor , when different reference values are considered , was developed in by Hoyos et al. Khubalkar et al. , in , presented for the DC/DC Buck converter driving a DC motor a digital implementation of a fractional order PID control , whose parameters are tuned through the improved inertia weight dPSO technique .
#Text=A flatness-based tracking control implemented in successive loops was presented by Rigatos et al. in .
#Text=More recently , the speed regulation problem was addressed by Yang et al. in , by using a robust predictive control via a discrete-time reduced-order GPI observer .
#Text=Additionally , other important contributions related to the connection of a DC/DC Buck converter and a DC motor have been reported in .
#Text=On the other hand , regarding a DC motor when it is fed by a DC/DC Buck converter – inverter , the literature is as follows .

#Text=In , Silva-Ortigoza et al. developed and experimentally validated a mathematical model associated with the DC/DC Buck converter – inverter – DC motor system . Silva-Ortigoza et al. reported , in , a passive tracking control based on the exact tracking error dynamics .
#Text=Robust tracking controls were proposed by Hernández-Márquez et al. in .
